instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hi again, I got this motherboard, it had corrosion on <RESISTOR>R7109</RESISTOR>, cleaned the pads and changed the resistor.
Still getting short on L7410, 7420 and 7430
Diode Mode on those coils are:
L7410/7420/7430 = 0.02

Edit
I found out that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> was shorted too what lead me to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Removed F7000 and have a short to ground on PIN 2 F7000
Resistance from PIN 2 from F7000 to ground is 1.6 ohm
From PIN2 F7000 to L7410/7420/7430 = 0.2 ohm

Should I replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> or is it a dead CPU already?
Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message:
Remove <CHIP>U7410</CHIP>/20/30 one by one.
Check when the short from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> disappears.
Then post exact ohm resistance to ground (not diode mode) at the same coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message:
I removed L7410, the short is gone on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Measured ohms on L7410
PIN 1 = 420
PIN 2 = 1.6
diode mode on:
F7000 PIN 2 = .165
L7410 PIN 1 = .002
L7410 PIN 2 = .165

This means dead CPU right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message:
0.002 in diode mode means 2-3 ohms.
ALWAYS switch to ohm mode for very low values.
However, this looks like good value.

Change <CHIP>U7410</CHIP> and be sure no short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> anymore, before applying power to the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message: Ok finally got <CHIP>U7410</CHIP> and replaced it, no short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but I connected it and it is consuming .350 A and when you first connect the usb c it will go up to .700A but have no image on screen

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
threads.message: Burnt <CHIP>U7410</CHIP> caused an overvoltage to CPU; letal damage probably...
